column3: A website where students can ask professionals questions about their work and career paths.
A checklist that helps students and advisors keep track of the tasks that have to be accomplished in order to complete the college application process.
A site that provides college & career planning resources, and posts information about upcoming  college-related events for guidance counselors and their students.
A site that strives to empower underserved, first-generation college students to and through college by providing critical information, guidance, scholarships, and ongoing support.(FROM SITE)
A standardized undergraduate college application form used by 488 institutions, designed to make applying to college easier for students.
A website that serves as a research tool to show available scholarships for pre-college and college students.
A website that equips job seekers with the advice, research, and inspiration they need to plan and achieve a successful career. (FROM SITE)

The official website of the City University of New York (CUNY).  It provides frequent updates about news and events at CUNY, and allows current and future students to find information about admissions, academics, and financial aid.

A website that offers college and career exploration videos, as well as other resources to help students connect to other students and share their stories.
A website that provides detailed, step-by-step information about how to prepare for college.  It includes resources for both middle and high school students.
The undergraduate admission application accepted by 52 of 64 campuses of the State University of New York (SUNY).

column3: A searchable database of colleges that helps students decide which schools might be best for them.

A college and career readiness platform that helps connect academic achievement to post-secondary goals.  Naviance tools are accessible to those students who have access through their schools or through a program in which they are enrolled.

column3: A list of questions for high school students to ask their school counselors about how to prepare for college and careers.
A video that includes professionals discussing the importance of middle school in preparing for college.
The hub for all CUNY admission information. Advisors and counselors can find admission updates, counseling resources, and links to RSVP to upcoming counselor events. (ADAPTED FROM SITE)

A website with a searchable database for jobs, internships, and volunteer opportunities, primarily with non-profit oganizations.

Videos documenting the ASAP orientation program, which familiarizes students with college expectations and builds community amongst ASAP students and staff.  ASAP, which stands for Accelerated Study in Associate Programs, is a program for students at CUNY community colleges.

column3: A video designed to aid parents in preparing their middle school and high school children for college entry.

column1: "College Bound: Admissions and Financial Aid" Video
column3: A video that discusses admission procedures and financial aid for college bound students.
A video in which experts discuss strategies for maintaining good communication between schools and parents of middle and high school students.

A program that is a comprehensive career exploration and planning program that includes a multiple aptitude test battery, an interest inventory, and various career planning tools designed to help students explore the world of work.
A college search site designed to help students find the best college suited towards their needs.
A website/organization that provides scholarships, as well as, college and professional development opportunities for Asian & Pacific Islander American students.

www.OptimalResume.com is a website that helps job seekers hone their interviewing skills online with real-to-life, multi-media interview scenarios that were developed by seasoned employment professionals.

NYColleges.org is a website that provides information and resources for college planning, specifically for private colleges in New York. Students can find information about private colleges and financial aid.

The New York State Financial Aid Administrators Association is an organization that offers education, professional development, and networking opportunities for professional members and for colleagues in related education, business, and governmental professions.
A directory of merit scholarships and academic scholarships from colleges across the country for students and guidance counselors.

A website that offers detailed information on colleges, grad schools, high schools, online education, and universities worldwide for students. It includes school rankings across different catagories such as major, school size, etc.

A blog helping parents get themselves and their children through the college admission process and helping teachers with issues encountered in the classroom and changes in education policy that affects their teaching.

A blog that features articles about college admissions, academics, college life, financial aid and planning, research on college rankings and evaluating schools for students. The author, Lynn O'Shaughnessy, is a best selling author, education consultant, speaker, financial journailst and mother.

A website created by The College Board containing college planning tips and tools for finding the right college match, completing applications and preparing for SAT's AP exams, PSAT/NMSQT exams. The site also has lots and lots of original videos of real college students talking about their challenges and success.

Created by The American Council on Education, Lumina Foundation for Education and the Ad Council, KnowHow2Go, gives step by step infromation to 8th - 10th graders on how to find the right college match, apply, finance and enroll in college.
The American Council on Education, Lumina Foundation for Education and the Ad Council launched the KnowHow2GO campaign in January 2007. This multiyear, multimedia effort includes television, radio and outdoor public service advertisements (PSAs) that encourage 8th through 10th graders to prepare for college using four simple steps.
The Four Steps to College
  • Be a pain - Let everyone know that you're going to college and need their help.
  • Push yourself - Working a little harder today will make getting into college even easier.
  • Find the right fit - Find out what kind of school is the best match for you and your career goals.
  • Put your hands on some cash - If you think you can't afford college, think again. There's lots of aid out there.
To ensure that students and adult mentors who connect with the powerful messages of the PSA campaign can easily find real-time, on-the-ground assistance, we have built and continue to support a strong grassroots network of partners. To date, 15 state and regional coalitions and 30 national partners have signed onto the campaign.

A College and career planning website provided by the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency (PHEAA) for students. The website has self-assesments, information on standardized tests, college search tools, college cost guides information for college advisers on setting up mentoring programs, career exploration activities and aligning work with ASCA standards.

A college research website that contains information about test prep, finding your ﾓdream schoolﾔ, exploring careers and college profile links to request information from featured schools for prospective students.
A website containing reviews of colleges and universities for students, by students.
A financial aid application process where aid is based on your family income.
A foundation that offers scholarship opportunities and resources to help address the barriers that keep many Latinos from earning a college degree.
A free and confidential information service that connects youth to jobs, afterschool programs and training opportunities for youth, adolescents, adults and families.
A hip hop video from Charta Squad with specifics about filing the FAFSA designed to better inform students.
A membership organization aims help to underrepresented students with academic preparation, placement services and counseling, and ongoing support to ensure enrollment at and graduation from college.
An online library of resources, lesson plans, research and activities for teachers of all subject matter and grade levels.

A network of community- based organizations, colleges, and secondary schools committed to assisting students in obtaining admission into institutions of higher education, for potential students. CACNY meets monthly and brings together college advisors, program managers, and college admissions professionals in order to increase their knowledge about college access and completion in order to better support students in NYC.

A nonprofit organization that aims to advance quality and equity in education for people worldwide by creating assessments based on rigorous research. ETS is reponsible for creating tests like GRE, TOEFLE and TOEIC, among others.

column1: Resources for Children with Special Needs
column3: A nonprofit organization that works for families and children with special needs, across all boroughs, to understand, navigate, and access the services needed to ensure that all children have the opportunity to develop their full potential. Resources for Children with Special Needs (RCSN) provides workshops special education, the NYC high school application process, among others. RCSN has two Soecial Education Parent Centers, in Manhatten and the Bronx.

A planning website that provides "real-world" advice for college-bound students. From making the descision where to apply to enrollment College Scoop gives step by step advice for students, parents on professionals on getting in and succeeding in college.
A program and website that selects 1000 students to receive a good-through-graduation scholarship to use at any college or university.

A search site built by students for students. Students at college and universities all over the country are surveyed to create an "insider's college guide". CollegeProwler.com has more than 200,000 student reviews and coverage on nearly 7,000 schools. Each month, more than 1 million high school and college students visit CollegeProwler.com to find and research schools and scholarships.

A search site for colleges and scholarships that also features test prep resources and articles. Careersandcolleges.com also has advice for high school students in the form of podcasts, blogs, and articles related to college admission, financial aid for students.

column3: A site full of resources for counselors seeking to support students in applying for and receiving federal student aid, created by the same U.S. Department that administers the FAFSA.

column3: A site containing reviews of K-12 public schools in NYC, including reviews posted by website users for students.
A site that contains information on scholarships, fellowships, internships, for African American students.
A site created to guide students on the complexity of the admissions and financial aid process.
A site geared towards teaching students about different college majors so they can make more informed college and career choices.
A site intended founded to "demystify" college admissions process, for high school students.

FairTest publishes a regular electronic newsletter, The Examiner, plus a full catalog of materials on both K- 12 and university testing to aid teachers, administrators, students, parents and researchers.  FairTest also has numerous fact sheets available to educate you on standardized testing and alternative assessment.

The purpose of the National Center for Education Statistics' website is to provide clear, complete information about NCES' mission and activities, and to serve the research, education and other interested communities.

Get Schooled has a variety of resources to help students prepare for and enroll in college. Their projects include: The College Dollars Challenge which helps students connect to scholarships and get answers to financial aid questions. Whole school competitions to increase attendance and recognize teachers and connect winning schools to celbreties like Nicki Minaj and Ne-Yo
A site that provides students and parents with advice about planning, preparing and paying for college.

A site for high school and college studensts that contains college and graduate school searches and information pertaining to majors and degrees, campus life, and contact info for prospective college students.
A site that contains information on loans, scholarships, savings, military aid, financial aid applications. This site also has cost calculators.
A site, created by the U.S. Deprtment of Education, for students,  that contains useful information about preparing for college, getting money for college and repaying loans for high school students.
A site, for students and working professionals, that contains videos about self improvement and career development.

A site that features a free online scholarship matching and college search service, in multiple areas aligning with student's educational goals, activities and interests. Fast Web was created for students and military service members.
A site that features an in-depth coverage of US schools and has a library of higher education and career articles for US students.

A site that focuses on college readiness, college connection and success as well as advocacy for students and counselors. Collegeboard.org contains information on SATs, PSATs, AP exams, as well as information on colleges and universities all over the country.
A site that manages grant, scholarship and loan programs (example: TAP and NYHELPs), as well as, features information on college and career planning, financial aid etc. for students.
A site that provides a free national directory of federally funded  college access programs for students, counselors, parents and researchers.

Career Zone includes detailed information on salary, educational requirements, job descriptions for a wide variety of careers. There are also a variety of self assesments to help students identify careers that would be a good fit for their interests and potential.
College View is a website that provides information on school statistics, SAT scores, locations, major areas of study, career planning, and financial aid.
A site that provides tips and advice for online students and information for students thinking about attending an online college.
A site that provides virtual college tours with 360ﾰ views of many different colleges as well as providing college planning, career exploration and financial aid information for students.
A site used to buy, sell and, rent new and used textbooks for students.

A site where questions about college are asked and answered by students, parents and admission experts alike. Questions range from financial aid, to study abroad, and include advice on majors and concentrations.

A site with an in-depth search engine of colleges and universities created by the National Center for Education Statistics for students. College Navigator allows you to search by degree type, location, and type of institution.
A source of news, information, and jobs for college and university faculty members and administrators.

A Spanish-language television series that provides a step-by-step guide for applying to college (available in Spanish and English). This is for junior & high school students, their families, their school and community organizations.
A student generated website for rating courses, professors, colleges and universities. You can also search for and rent text books. This website is for college students.
This site provides information about SUNY, specifically for high school counselors.
A user friendly site and a research tool designed to help shed light on important trends and issues, for professionals.

A user-created directory of educational organizations, individuals and schools for students, parents, educators, school leaders and policy makers. Organizations can create free profiles on LinkEd to make their information public and searchable in a simple, organized fashion. Individuals are able to create free profiles to find job opportunities, connect with other people in the same field, find resources to help their school, child or classroom, and discover ways to enhance their children's educational experience.

A professional membership organization designed to give counseling and admission professionals the tools they need to improve the counseling they provide to students. You can find information on college fairs, conferences, events, networking, research and advocacy on ther website.
A website that connects potential college students to college admissions represnetatives through live chat.
A website that allows students to compare graduation rates for different colleges and universities.
A website that let students connect with, get recruited by, and interact with colleges and universities worldwide, as well as match students to any scholarship out there.

A website that features research and data relating to student debt, publications, news, information on initiatives, student debt policy agenda, and ways to take action. The intended audience is professionals and policy makers.

The official website of the State University of New York.  It provides frequent updates about news and events at SUNY, and allows current and future students to find information about admissions, academics, and financial aid.

A professioanl network that helps organizations better serve their students better by providing programs with up-to-date tools and resources, connecting them to each other, and informing them of developments in the field.  NCAN hosts an annual conference, publishes reports and supports college advocacy efforts across the country.

A website that helps students find with colleges and scholarships that are right for them. Students create a profile and answer questions about themselves so Cappex can find them the best matches.
Cappex connects you to: Scholarships, Merit Aid Offered by Colleges, College Matching, College Reviews, College Information, and Visual Admission Scattergrams

The Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS) administers internship programs to introduce college students and recent graduates to public service. Through the Urban Fellows Program, and the Public Service Corps, college students/recent graduates receive valuable work experience in exchange for academic credit or stipends, depending on the program. The Urban Fellows Program is open to graduates no more than two years out of college. For more information about the Urban Fellows Program call 311 or dial (212) NEW-YORK if outside of NYC. The NYC Service Fellowship offers a unique opportunity to obtain practical City government experience in the areas of volunteerism and community service at the City level. Please be aware that there has been a change to the notification timeline for this fellowship. Interviews will likely be held the week of June 18, 2012 and all candidates will be notified of their status, by email, before June 18. The Public Service Corps (PSC) is open to undergraduate and graduate students eligible for Federal Work-Study Program internships. For more information about the PSC call 311 or dial (212) NEW-YORK if outside of NYC. (Application deadline: Seasonal) In addition to the DCAS internship programs, a number of City agencies independently offer summer internships. DCAS coordinates the Citywide Summer Internship Program, which includes hundreds of paid and unpaid internship opportunities in agencies throughout the City. (Application deadline: January to May) NYC Internship / Fellowship Programs, Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS), Division of Citywide Personnel Services, 1 Centre Street, 24th Floor, New York, NY 10007, Please note: The Fellowship Programs do not provide student loans, financial aid or scholarship for study.

UNCF plays a critical role in enabling more than 60,000 students each year to attend college and get the education they need and that the nation needs them to have. To live up to the ideal expressed in UNCF's universally-recognized motto, ﾔA mind is a terrible thing to waste,ﾔﾮ UNCF helps students go to and through college by:
  • Awarding 10,000 students each year through 400 scholarship and internship programs so that students from low- and moderate-income families can afford college tuition, books and room and board;
  • Providing operating funds for its 38 member colleges, all of them small, private institutions that offer a small-college experience at tuitions that average more than 30 percent less than those at comparable colleges and universities;
  • Serving as a national advocate for the importance of education for all Americans by serving as the voice of students of color through its annual television program, UNCF An Evening of Starsﾮ, a national public service announcement campaign built around ﾓA mind is a terrible thing to wasteﾔﾮ and commentary in national media.

A website that provides curricular materials and books developed for students who are first in their family to pursue higher education. Reach for College trains teachers to use these materieals in public high schools and charter schools. There are resources on theer website for educators, students and parents.

This weekly email searches main media outlets finding stories that may be of interest to high school counselors, college admission officers and related organizations, with links to the original stories.

College Summit is an organization that  works in partnership with schools, school districts and colleges to develop a sustainable model for raising college enrollment rates community-wide. Their website has information for school administrators and education advocates about best practice research and their work.

Advocates for Children of New York are dedicated exclusively to protecting every child's right to an education, focusing on students from low-income backgrounds who are struggling in school or experiencing school discrimination of any kind. For more than 40 years, their staff of attorneys and education specialists have successfully helped hundreds of thousands of families by providing free legal and advocacy services, including representation at school-related hearings and appeals, and teaching families what they need to know to stand up for their children's educational rights.  AFC also works to change education policy so that the public school system serves ALL children of New York City effectively.  For more information about Policy & Initiatives and Litigation, please click on the links.

An organization that assists their members (independent counselors) serve families in educational decisions.  IECA sponsors professional training institutes, workshops and conferences, publishes a directory of qualified independent educational consultants, offers information to students and their families regarding school selection issues and works to ensure that those in the profession adhere to the highest ethical and business standards.
The Higher Education ConsultantsﾠAssociation is a professional organization focused exclusively on the practice of independent college admissions consulting.

Kahn Acadmey has over 3,400 FREE videos that cover K-12 topics including;  math, science, finance and economics,  humanities, and test prep.  The website allows to you to track you to create an account and track your activity.
An organization that provides leadership training, publications, continuing education opportunities, and advocacy services for their professional members.
A website that aims to ﾓhelp students find the right pathﾔ by producing college, career and life planning guides for high school students, counselors, and parents.

A worksheet to help students compare financial aid packages from different schools. Students fill in  the details of two to three  financial aid packages in order to understand exactly how they compare in terms of how much students will pay.

column1: New York State Association for College Admissions Counseling (NYSACAC)
column3: An association that provides leadership and professional development opportunities in college admission counseling for college counselors.

An educational blog featuring a panel of experts that try to address queries on issues ranging from financial aid to how to improve your chances of being admitted off a waitlist. The Choice is  for students and counselors.
An evaluative worksheet that assesses your "values" and what's important to you. This assesment is good for any person interested in finding out more about themselves.
An interactive website created by the New York State Education Services Corporation (HESC), to help students apply to college, learn what to expect in college, and how to succeed in college.

column1: The College Board's Net Price Calculator
column3: An online tool to help you calculate how much college will really cost you, minus scholarships and grants, for students.

MALDEF is the nation's leading Latino legal civil rights organization. MALDEF promotes social change through advocacy, communications, community education, and litigation in the areas of education, employment, immigrant rights, and political access.
An organization that provides education, networking, and public advocacy to empower its members to achieve career success and financial security. Designed for female professionals.

An organization that provides valuable information, news and resources, which address current issues in higher education as well as common misperceptions about the college search process for students. CTCL works to dispel publicly held myths about college choice--particularly the notion that college choices are severely limited to today's high school students--by hosting information sessions nationwide and coordinating outreach efforts with high school counselors and college counseling agencies alike.

column1: Training for Trainers: A Guide to Designing Interactive Trainings Using Popular Education Techniques
column3: This handbook is a product of the Research Center for Leadership in Action (RCLA) at New York University's Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service. It was developed as part of a learning session offered through the RCLA Social Change Leadership Network, an initiative manﾭaged by Deputy Director Amparo Hofmann-Pinilla with advisement from Faculty Director Sonia Ospina and Executive Director Bethany Godsoe. The Social Change Leadership Network is an initiative that supports and enhances social change leadership through participatory research, documentation and dissemination of knowledge from the field. It facilitates opportunities for leadership development, organizational capacity buildﾭing and dialogue. The Network also strengthens the relationship between academics and social change organizers by creating dynamic communities of practice through peer-to-peer learning, intergenerational exchange, dialogue, inquiry, action learning and knowledge building. It relies on the wisdom of a cadre of experienced social change leaders and regular input from grassroots nonprofit organizations on the most pressing needs they face as they work to deepen civic parﾭticipation and make social transformation possible.

column1: The Association of Black Admissions and Financial Aid Officers of the Ivy League and Sister Schools
column3: Recognizing the unique challenges facing African American, Native American, Latino, and Hispanic students during the college admissions process, the Association of Black Admissions and Financial Aid Officers of the Ivy League and Sister Schools (ABAFAOILSS) was founded in 1970 to provide vital assistance for these students as they make the transition from high school to college.

column1: ﾿Puede solicitar ayuda para pagar la colegiatura?

SUNY Center for Professional Development (CPD) is a collaborative central resource for the SUNY Community providing access to high quality professional development opportunities focused on the latest trends and established best practices in higher education to enhance the capability of SUNY faculty and staff and increase SUNY's competitive advantage.
TAP is New York States Tuition Assistance Program (TAP) that provides financial aid to NYS residents attending NYS schools.

The CUNY portal is a gateway to all things CUNY: college websites, information about applying to CUNY, registering for classes, events, campus directories, etc. While most of this information was previously available, the CUNY portal makes it easier and faster to find what you need. And if you register on the portal, the ability to customize your view will make future visits to the portal more productive.

A website created for all creative students and recent graduates looking for one place to find internships, part-time work, and full-time entry-level jobs in Graphic Design, Industrial Design, Web Design, Architecture, Fashion Design, & Interior Design.

A website for students to explore colleges, degree programs and careers. Yahoo Education has college search tools and articles about college and careers.

A website, developed by the President's Advisory Council on Financial Capability, which provides 20 essential, age-appropriate financial lessonsﾗwith corresponding activitiesﾗthat kids need to know as they grow.
A website based on the bestselling book which tells you how to deal with college life and includes a friendly online community of students to support other students.
A blog that supports peer networking among current college students by connecting peers to each other in order to get unbiased support, feedback and resources for particular problems.

column3: The Bureau of Labor Statistics' website contains career data primarily used for career exploration by students and professionals. This website has information about salary, required training, job availability for all careers.
Mapping Your Future is your free resource for career, college, financial aid, and money management information.
An online guide produced by Columbia University,Teachers College Career Services on writing an effective resume.

column3: An online guide produced by Columbia University,Teachers College Career Services on writing an effective cover letter.

column3: An online information sheet for school guidance counselors produced by the New York City Department of Education, Office of Youth Development, and the United Federation of Teachers Guidance Counselor Chapter.

This CUNY webpage lists notable academic programs for college students. Links to opportunity, scholarship, writing, justice, leadership, language immersion, teaching, media, and transtion programs can be found on this page.
An education search engine that helps anyone find educational opportunities at all levels, from K-12 to college, grad school, weekend classes, and professional development.
An national internship program that develops and places talented underserved youth in business and industry, and prepares them for corporate and community leadership.

An internship program that recruits and trains outstanding college students of color for summer internships that lead to full-time jobs with investment banks, corporate law firms, and other leading global companies
An internship list created by Ed2010, a group of young editors and editor assistants who support young people exploring careers in media.
An organization that provides mentoring, readings, and workshops focused around professional and creative writing for girls from NYC public high schools.

column2: What Do I Really Want in a College?
column3: This is a checklist for students to use when trying to determine what qualities they are looking for in a college.  It helps determine what type of setting, academic programs, extracurricular activities, support, and locations a student is looking for.

column1: Developing a Strategic List of Colleges for Each Student
column3: This is a tool for counselors and advisors to help develop strong, well-balanced college lists with their students.  It includes the dos and don'ts of good college lists, the process for creating a list, as well as how to assess difficulty and what college criteria to take into account.

column1: Options Tool for Creating a List of Recommended Colleges
column3: A chart college counselors and advisors can use to create a list of recommended colleges that are a good match for their students.

column3: This document includes resources that college counselors and advisors can use to research colleges and universities.  It describes where to find these tools and what each tool is best used for.

column3: This document clearly and concisely explains percentiles and medians.  It is helpful for understanding grades and scores and how they relate to whether a college is a most, moderately, or least difficult fit (reach, target, or safety).
column6: Options > NYC College Line > Uploaded Resources

column1: What to Look for in a College and Researching Colleges
column3: This document helps a student decide what they are looking for in colleges, including factors to keep in mind while exploring.  It also includes a college research guide has information about tools, where to find them, how to use resources, and what to look for.

column3: This is a list of programs that are an alternative to college, including accreditation programs, gap-year programs, apprenticeships, and many more. It includes a brief description of each and is a great resource for counseling students who are not sure if college is the right next step for them.

column3: This helpful tool can be used by college advisors/counselors and students to organize their college research to keep track of different college qualities and whether they match what the student is looking for in a college.

column3: This document describes the purpose of the college application essay, the counselor's role, and techniques for providing feedback to students on multiple drafts of their essays.

column3: The ARROW Method is a tool for providing constructive feedback on student essays.  It is a helpful tool for counselors/advisors who help students with college admissions essays.

column1: Helping Students Start a College Essay
column3: For many students, the most difficult part of the college essay is starting it - coming up with ideas, knowing the format, outlining, etc.  This tool for counselors and advisors gives suggestions for how to help students start essays.  It also includes a template for a 5 paragraph essay.

column3: This tool includes tips for writing college recommendations for students.  It details the objectives of writing recommendations and how to effectively meet them.  It also includes an outline template.

column3: This document includes a chart that is useful for reading and reviewing college recommendations written for students.  It notes items to make sure your recommendation should include to help the student submit the strongest application they can.

column3: This tool helps students design, organize, and determine what to include in their resume.  It includes examples and a chart the student can fill out to determine what to include.

column3: This resource helps students with college interviews by describing what to expect, questions that may be asked, how to prepare, and the importance of asking questions.

column3: This resource describes the importance of extracurricular activities and how to include them in resumes and college applications.
column6: Options > NYC College Line > Uploaded Resources

column3: This document is designed to help students call colleges, which is often necessary during the college application process to confirm that all materials are received, to ask for clarification, and to advocate for oneself.

column3: This document includes four sample transcripts that counselors, parents, and students can use to get a sense of what information can be found on a college transcript.

column3: This is the front page of the GED website and covers the basics of the current GED test for counselors and people looking to get their GED.
This web page answers many frequently asked questions about the GED test, including information about eligibility, preparation, scoring, testing accommodations, and getting results.
This fact sheet covers the content, history, and use of the GED test.   It also includes data on test takers, scores, and links to more resources.
This two page document explains the GED scores and how to interpret results on different sections.  It explains the meaning of the numbers, the percentiles, and the other results categories.

column1: Minimum GED Test Scores to be Considered for Admissions at CUNY Colleges
column3: This document lists the minimum GED scores needed to be considered for admissions at the different CUNY Colleges.

column3: This website explains the new photo requirements for SAT test takers.
This website lists 4-year colleges and universities that do not require SAT or ACT scores to be considered for admission.
This website lists ACT scores and the comprable SAT score allowing quick and easy comparison between SAT and ACT scores.
This website provides an overview of the TOEFL test, what it is used for, what it entails, who should take it, and other frequently asked questions.
This website breaks down TOEFL test scores and what they mean for test takers and advisors.

column1: TOEFL Fee Reduction Service Voucher Request Form 2012-2013
column3: This is the TOEFL fee reduction voucher request form for 2012-2013 that counselors can fill out to get students a reduced fee on the TOEFL test.
This website provides an overview of CUNY's SEEK program.  It outlines eligibility requirements, how to apply, and answers to common questions.
This website provides an overview of CUNY's College Discovery program.  It outlines eligibility requirements, how to apply, and answers to common questions.

This PDF lists the freshman class overview at all CUNY colleges for the incoming and transfer class of 2012.  It includes mean GPA, SAT, and ACT scores, information for Macaulay Honors College, and SEEK/CD information.

This Information Summary lists details and scores for all of the Educational Opportunity Programs (EOP) at SUNY colleges, universities, colleges of technology, and community colleges.  It also includes information on what the EOP is, who is eligible, and EOP income guidelines.
This fact sheet provides an overview of the Higher Education Opportunity Program (HEOP), including what it is, who it serves, as well as its history and successes.

column1: GED Tips for Candidates with Disabilities
column3: This pamphlet by the GED Testing Service provides tips and suggestions for people with disabilities to consider before, during, and after taking the test.
This article describes the significance of the changes to the GED in 2014 and includes reactions and suggestions by people in the field.

column1: ACE and Pearson Collaborate to Transform GED Test - Press Release
column3: This press release announces the planned changes to the GED to align it with the Common Core State Standards.
This worksheet, developed by the Options Institute, is a tool for students and counselors to check that all requirements for classes and Regents are being met.

column3: This is a guide by the College Board on creating a college-going culture in schools.  It gives examples of best practices and tools counselors can use to create an environment in their schools that takes seriously each student's postsecondary potential.
This article from the New York Times, written by the Dean of Admissions at College of the Holy Cross, describes what that college looks for in a transcript.
This website provides guidelines and recommendations for how colleges should look at GED candidates that apply to their college/university.
This is the College Board's response to frequently asked questions about the fee waiver for the SAT, including how to obtain and use the waivers.

column3: This document, created by the ACT, describes eligibility requirements for fee waivers for the ACT including submission forms, distribution forms, and suggestions for advising eligible students.
This ACT website explains the difficulties of understanding ACT and SAT concordance and is a useful resource when trying to understand ACT scores.

column1: TOEFL Fee Reduction Guidelines and Procedures
column3: This site details student eligibility requirements, procedures for counselors, procedures for students, and important information to keep in mind when applying for TOEFL fee reduction.

column1: New Photo Requirements on SAT Will Not Affect Undocumented Students
column3: This article on Colorlines.com explains that the new photo ID requirements for the SAT will not affect undocumented students.  It includes a statement from the College Board.
This article from the Washington Post describes how the NY cheating scandal prompted the new photo requirements on the SAT and ACT tests.

This guide was developed by the Higher Education Opportunity Program (HEOP) to inform counselors of the "numerous opportunities at independent colleges and universities in New York State through the Arthur O. Eve Higher Education Opportunity Program (HEOP)"

column1: What's My GPA on a 4.0 Scale
column3: This is a GPA conversion chart that allows students and counselors to convert GPAs on a 100-point scale into GPAs on a 4.0 scale, and to see what letter grade that correlates to.
This is a map of all the colleges and universities in the City University of New York system.
This is a map of all the colleges and universities in the State University of New York system.

column1: Mileage from NYC to SUNY Campuses
column3: This website lists the mileage and travel time from New York City to all of the SUNY campuses.

This PDF lists the freshman class overview at all SUNY colleges for the incoming class of 2012.  It includes enrollment numbers, SAT and ACT scores, mean GPA, and other information about what is available at each campus, including sports.

column1: SUNY Community College Admissions Information Summary
column3: This PDF lists the SUNY community colleges and their enrollment numbers for full-time and part-time students.  It provides information on programs and services provided at each college, including whether student housing is available and what sports teams are at each college.

This PDF lists the SUNY honors programs by college and university type.  It includes undergraduate and freshman enrollment numbers; mean SAT scores, ACT scores, and GPA; and the contact person at each program.

column1: Proprietary Schools: Making the Numbers Count
column3: This publication by the National Consumer Law Center explains the data around proprietary schools, the risk the data show for students, and what can be done about it.

column1: List of Proprietary Colleges in New York State
column3: This is a list of New York State proprietary colleges and university campuses.

column1: Database of Accredited Postsecondary Institutions and Programs
column3: This is the front page of the database of accredited postsecondary institutions and programs.  It explains the role of accreditation, has a short explanation of the database, and provides a link to search the database or download a full list of accredited programs.

column1: Definitions of Admission Options in Higher Education
column3: This document, developed by the National Association for College Admision Counseling (NACAC), describes the different admission types - including Early Decision, Early Action, and Regular Decision - and which process best suits which students.
This is the brochure for CUNY's Accelerated Study in Associate Programs.  It includes an overview, information about how to apply, and details about selection criteria.
This is the informational sheet for students about the CUNY Language Immersion Program.  It provides an overview, fees, locations, and other basic information about the program.
This website provides an overview of CUNY's Start program.  It describes who the program is for and describes full time and part time enrollment options.

This is the Frequently Asked Questions page from CUNY Start's website.  It answers a range of questions about enrollment, eligibility, and provides more information about the program before, during, and after entering CUNY Start.

This guide to writing resumes, developed by Hamilton College, includes tools for students writing resumes for jobs or when applying to college.  It includes an overview of the format, content, and style of resumes; a brainstorm section; a list of action verbs to use; and sample resumes.
This sheet is designed for students to use when they call colleges.  It includes space for students to write the questions they will ask, record the answers, note contacts, and fill in next steps.
